Kernewek: Eus flogh dhedhi?
English: Has she a child?

Kernewek: Eus! Yma flogh dhedhi.
English: Yes! She has a child.

Kernewek: Esa kath dhedha?
English: Did they have a cat?

Kernewek: Esa! Yth esa kath dhedha
English: Yes! They had a cat.

Kernewek: Eus ki ganso?
English: Has he a dog with him?

Kernewek: Eus! Yma ki ganso
English: Yes! He has a dog with him.

Kernewek: Eus flogh gensi?
English: Is there a child with her?

Kernewek: Esa koweth genes?
English: Did you have a friend with you?

Kernewek: Esa! Yth esa koweth genev.
English: Yes! I had a friend with me.

Kernewek: Yw an bluvenn ma dhis?
English: Is this pen yours?

Kernewek: Yw! An bluvenn yw dhymm.
English: It is! The pen is mine.

Kernewek: Nag yw! Nyns yw an bluvenn dhymm.
English: It is not! The pen is not mine.

Kernewek: O an lyver dhe Yowann?
English: Was the book John's?

Kernewek: O! An lyver o dhe Yowann.
English: Yes! It was John's book.

Kernewek: Nag o! Nyns o an lyver dhe Yowann.
English: No! The book was not John's.

Kernewek: Eus jynn-amontya dhis? Nag eus!
English: Have you a computer? No!

Kernewek: Eus kadoryow-bregh dhedhi? Eus!
English: Has she got armchairs? Yes!

Kernewek: Yma diw gador-vregh dhedhi.
English: She has two armchairs.

Kernewek: Nyns eus tigenn nowydh dhymm.
English: I have not got a new wallet. .

Kernewek: Yma nebes pelyow dhe'n fleghes.
English: The children have a few balls.

Kernewek: Eus hanow dhe'n ki ma?
English: Has this dog got a name?

Kernewek: Esa le'ti dhe'n bargen-tir na?
English: Had that farm a dairy?

Kernewek: Nyns esa keow ledan dhe'n pras.
English: The field did not have wide hedges.

Kernewek: Eus esedhva vras dhe'n chi na?
English: Has that house a large lounge?

Kernewek: Eus! Yma onan pur vras dhodho.
English: Yes! It has a large one.

Kernewek: Eus kath gensi? Nag eus lemmyn.
English: Has she a cat with her? Not now!

Kernewek: Esa aga broder gansa?
English: Did they have their brother with them?

Kernewek: Yw an dhewweder ma dhis?
English: Are these spectacles yours?

Kernewek: Yns. I yw dhymm, meur ras.
English: Yes. They are mine, thanks.

Kernewek: Yw an wedrenn ma dhedhi? Yw!
English: Is this her glass? Yes!

Kernewek: A nyns yw an nessa karr dhe Vr Martyn?
English: Isn't the next car Mr Martin's?

Kernewek: Yw! Ev yw dhe Vr Martyn, dell dybav.
English: Yes! It's Mr Martin's, I think.

Kernewek: O an eskisyow dhedha? Ens!
English: Were the shoes theirs? Yes!

Kernewek: A nyns o an diwes na dhe Wella?
English: Wasn't that Wella's drink?

Kernewek: Nag o! Dhe Gerensa o.
English: No! It was Karenza's.

Kernewek: My a verrhas ow hows mes ny verrhasons aga hows ynsi.
English: I cut short my speech but they did not cut short their speech.

Kernewek: Tasik! Tasik! Ottena! Ergh war an glesin!
English: Daddy! Daddy! Look! Snow on the lawn!

Kernewek: Aga chi yw gwerthys y'n eur ma.
English: Their house is sold now.

Kernewek: Dha weles Dy' Meurth martesen!
English: See you (on) Tuesday perhaps!

Kernewek: Niver an gorholyon y'n porth yw eth.
English: The number of ships in the harbour is eight. .

Kernewek: Hedhyw yw an dewdhegves a vis Meurth, pennbloedh ow gwreg.
English: Today is the twelfth of March, my wife's birthday.

Kernewek: Ro dhymm an hoelan, mar pleg!
English: Give me the salt, please!

Kernewek: Ple'ma an gerlyver Kernewek?
English: Where is the Cornish dictionary?

Kernewek: War drysa estyllenn an argh-lyvrow y'n esedhva yma, dell dybav.
English: On the third shelf of the bookcase in the lounge it is, I think.

Kernewek: Yth esa ke isel a-dal an chi.
English: There was a low hedge opposite the house.

Kernewek: Nyns esa tra arall a-dal dhodho.
English: There was nothing else opposite it.

Kernewek: Yth esa pastiow yeyn rag agan kroust. Bryntin!
English: There were cold pasties for our crib. Fine!

Kernewek: Yth esov ow mires orth an gorholyon ena.
English: I am looking at the ships there.

Kernewek: Hi a wiskas hy fows las.
English: She wore her blue dress.

Kernewek: Ny evav ten a koffi herwydh usadow.
English: I don't drink tea nor coffee usually.

Kernewek: Pan dhewelav tre, an teylu yw lowen.
English: When I return home, the family is happy.

Kernewek: Mona re gollas hy arghans.
English: Mona has lost her money.

Kernewek: An gath a gosk war an gweliow.
English: The cat sleeps on the beds.

Kernewek: Ena y lammas an vugh dres an ke.
English: Then the cow jumped over the hedge.

Kernewek: Mr Evans, an tiek, a vag deves ha hoghes.
English: Mr Evans, the farmer, breeds sheep and cows.

Kernewek: Glanha an bord du ragov, mar pleg.
English: Clean the blackboard for me, please.

Kernewek: Ny gyrghsons aga thaklow gansa.
English: They didn't bring their things with them.

Kernewek: An vodrep Me a dorras bleujennow yn hy lowarth.
English: Aunt May picked flowers in her garden.

Kernewek: Dowr an fenten a dhe'n gover.
English: The spring water goes to the brook.

Kernewek: Ny wra ev y hwel. Diek yw ev.
English: He doesn't do his work. He is lazy.

Kernewek: Ev yw diwedhes pupprys.
English: He is always late.

Kernewek: Ammeth yw tra vras yn Kernow.
English: Agriculture is a big affair in Cornwall.

Kernewek: Oll an dus a asas an kuntelles warbarth.
English: All the people left the meeting together.

Kernewek: Oll anedha a drelyas a-dhistowgh.
English: All of them turned straightaway.

Kernewek: Oll ahanan a ganas y'n keur na.
English: All of us sang in that choir.

Kernewek: Kernowyon oll, keffrys koth ha yowynk.
English: Cornish people all, both old and young.

Kernewek: Meur ras dhywgh hwi oll.
English: Thank you all.

Kernewek: Nebes a lever yndella.
English: A few people say so.

Kernewek: Nebes geryow yw gwella.
English: A few words are best.

Kernewek: Nebes ahanowgh hwi a vydh dewisys.
English: A few of you will be chosen.

Kernewek: Nebes leth yw gesys.
English: A little milk is left.

Kernewek: Nebes anodho o poder.
English: A little of it was rotten.

Kernewek: Nyns eus karr vyth y'n fordh.
English: There is no car at all on the road.

Kernewek: A leveris ev travyth? Ger vyth!
English: Did he say anything? Not a word!

Kernewek: A welsys jy an edhen na? Travyth!
English: Did you see that bird? I didn't see anything!

Kernewek: Ev a leveris mann.
English: He said nothing.

Kernewek: Ny drelyas onan anedha a-dhistowgh.
English: Not one of them turned straightaway.

Kernewek: Ny ganas onan ahanan y'n keur na.
English: None of us sang in that choir.

Kernewek: Ev a welas ros a horn.
English: He saw an iron wheel.

Kernewek: Yw an amari ma gwrys a brenn-derow?
English: Is this cupboard made of oak wood?

Kernewek: Ugens a'n fleghes a wortas a-dhelergh.
English: Twenty of the children waited behind.

Kernewek: Kans anedha a dhehwelis.
English: A hundred of them returned.

Kernewek: Ystynn dhymm nebes leth, mar pleg. Yma syghes dhymm.
English: Pass me some milk, please. I'm thirsty.

Kernewek: Oll ahanan a yll gorthybi dhe'n govynn na.
English: All of us can answer that question.

Kernewek: Oll an gerens yw marow lemmyn.
English: All the near relations are dead now.

Kernewek: Nebes a'n hynwyn yw kernewek, dell hevel.
English: Some of the names are Cornish, it seems.

Kernewek: A-barth oll ahanan, 'Meur ras!'.
English: On behalf of all of us, 'Thanks!'.

Kernewek: Yw oll ahanowgh parys?
English: Are you all ready?

Kernewek: Nyns eus denvydh omma kynth yw hi seyth eur lemmyn.
English: There's no one here although it's seven o'clock now.

Kernewek: Nyns yw onan ahanowgh krev lowr dhe sevel an men ma.
English: Not one of you is strong enough to lift this stone.

Kernewek: An pastiow da ma yw gwrys a vewin. An vamm a brenas an kig yn kikti Mr Ross, an kiger. Ev a werth an gwella bewin.
English: These good pasties are made of beef. Mother bought the meat in Mr. Ross' butcher's shop. He sells the best beef.

Kernewek: An bowjiow yw gwrys a brenn.
English: The cowsheds are made of wood.

Kernewek: An hwegynnow na o gwrys a sugra gwynnrudh.
English: Those sweets were made of pink sugar.

Kernewek: Ass yns teg, pennow an menydhyow y'n howlsedhes, an howl rudh a-ughta.
English: How beautiful the tops of the mountains are in the sunset, the red sun above them.

Kernewek: Ny wonn konvedhes travydh yn y gever.
English: I don't understand anything about it.

Kernewek: Pandr'a leveris Maria yn kever Manow? Ny leveris hi ger yn hy hever.
English: What did Mary say about the Isle of Man? She didn't say a word about it.

Kernewek: An leth y'n badell a brojyas yn kettermyn ha'n dowr y'n galter.
English: The milk in the saucepan boiled at the same time as the water in the kettle.

Kernewek: Yma hwans dhymm a wovynn henna orth Jenefer po yn hy le nebonan arall.
English: I want to ask Jenifer that or in her place someone else.

Kernewek: An pyskador a dennas an ankor ha'n kok a woelyas a-dhistowgh.
English: The fisherman pulled the anchor and the boat sailed straight away.

Kernewek: I a balas kleudh down a-dro dhe'n park-kerri.
English: They dug a deep trench around the car park.

Kernewek: Fisten, fisten! Yma ergh ow tos!
English: Hurry, hurry! There's snow coming!

Kernewek: Piw a armas yndella?
English: Who shouted like that?

Kernewek: Kommol loes a dhre glaw.
English: Grey clouds bring rain.

Kernewek: Fatell o y worthyp? Ass o gokki!
English: How was his reply? How silly it was!

Kernewek: Ottomma! Ow gols. My re dennas dew vlewynn wynn diworto!
English: See here! My hair. I've pulled two white hairs from it!

Kernewek: Yowann a wovynnas orth an tiek, 'Py par gwydh yns i?' Ev a worthybis, 'Derow yns'.
English: John asked the farmer, 'What sort of trees are they?' He replied, 'They are oaks.'

Kernewek: Oll an fleghes a arm, 'Kernow bys vykken!' Pes da ov vy a henna.
English: All the children shout, 'Cornwall for ever!' I am pleased at that.

Kernewek: Yma peder ros dhe bub karr. Yma an pympes a-ji ynno.
English: Every car has four wheels. The fifth one is inside it.

Kernewek: Yma nown dhe'n vebyon. An vamm a vynn ri nebes boes dhedha. Mes eus boes lowr y'n yeynell? Eus. Yma meur a vara hag amanenn gesys hwath ynwedh.
English: The boys are hungry. Mother will give them some food. But is there enough food in the refrigerator? Yes! There is a lot of bread and butter still left as well.

Kernewek: Esedh a-dhelergh, mar pleg. Nyns eus le gesys rybov.
English: Sit at the back, please. There's no place left beside me.

Kernewek: Ty a vydh meur dhe les omma owth oberi genen.
English: You will be very useful here working with us.

Kernewek: Yth esen ow redya an paper-nowodhow ha my ow tybri.
English: I was reading the newspaper while I was eating.

Kernewek: Golgh dha dhiwleuv kyns dybri dha voes!
English: Wash your hands before eating your food!

Kernewek: Tas a gosk yn ta wosa oberi yn tiwysek.
English: Father sleeps well after working hard.

Kernewek: Kyns y vos dyskador, souder o.
English: Before he was a teacher he was a soldier.

Kernewek: Wosa agan gweles ev eth tre.
English: After seeing us he went home.

Kernewek: Yth esen a'm esedh hag i ow tonsya.
English: I was sitting while they were dancing.

Kernewek: Yma Peder ow kolghi fos yn unn stevell ha'y wreg ow liwya fosow an stevell arall.
English: Peter is washing a wall in one room while his wife is painting the walls of the other room.

Kernewek: Yth esa an vamm a'y sav ha'n fleghes ow kwari.
English: Mother was standing while the children were playing.

Kernewek: Yma perghenn an boesti ow jynn-skrifa gans unn bys hag ev ow megi yn keth prys.
English: The owner of the restaurant is typing with one finger while smoking at the same time.

Kernewek: Yth esens i a'ga gorwedh y'ga gweli ha'n vamm ow pareusi aga hansel.
English: They were lying in bed while mother was preparing their breakfast.

Kernewek: Omwolgh ha my owth omwiska!
English: Wash while I am dressing!

Kernewek: Wosa redya an dowlenn my a geskewsis yn hy hever gans ow gour.
English: After reading the programme I talked about it with my husband.

Kernewek: An drehevyans o melin goth kyns y vos diwotti, herwydh y berghenn.
English: The building was an old mill before it was a pub, according to its owner.

Kernewek: Karol a lanhas an lestri kyns aga daskorr dhe'n lestrier.
English: Carol cleaned the dishes before returning them to the dresser.

Kernewek: An gewer yw hager war an heyl. Ny yll den gweles a-dreus dhodho.
English: The weather is ugly on the estuary. A person cannot see across it.

Kernewek: Mir orth an pons! Yma puskes y'n avon yn-danno.
English: Look at the bridge! There are fish in the river under it.

Kernewek: An hyns yw efan mes leun a dus yw ev.
English: The road is wide but it is full of people.

Kernewek: Ke dhe-ves! Pur skwith ov.
English: Go away! I am very tired.

Kernewek: Nevra ny vynn hi dehweles ha homm yw kales.
English: She will never wish to return and that is hard.

Kernewek: An tiek a dhros y vughes dhe'n skiber.
English: The farmer brought his cows to the barn.

Kernewek: An rewler a worras an lytherow war an desk rybdho.
English: The manager put the letters on the desk beside him.

Kernewek: Yma euth dhymm. My a glewas tros ughel yn-mes y'n lowarth.
English: I'm terrified. I heard a loud noise outside in the garden.

Kernewek: Ottena! A-dro dhe hanterkans hos war an lynn yn kres an hal.
English: Look there! About fifty ducks on the lake in the middle of the moor.

Kernewek: Ymons i ow neuvya warbarth.
English: They are swimming together.

Kernewek: Res yw dhe Vr Richards mos dh'y soedhva pub dydh mes soweth diwedhes yw ev treweythyow.
English: Mr Richards must go to his office every day but unfortunately he is sometimes late.

Kernewek: Ny welsons an kert orth an gornell.
English: They did not see the lorry at the corner.

Kernewek: Pow pell yw Ejyp ha tir bras yw ynwedh.
English: Egypt is a distant country and it is large also.

Kernewek: Usi an lytherva ogas dhe hel an dre? Usi!
English: Is the post office near the town hall? Yes!

Kernewek: An peswara drehevyans diworto yw ev a'n keth tu.
English: It's the fourth building from it on the same side.

Kernewek: Goel Sen Pyran a vydh pub blydhen dhe'n pympes a vis Meurth.
English: St Piran's Day is on the fifth of March each year.

Kernewek: Tus pals a dhe'n eglos y'gan gwlas dhe'n jydh na.
English: Many people go to church in our land on that day.

Kernewek: Ple'ma bedh Sen Pyran hedhyw? Piw a woer?
English: Where is St Piran's grave today? Who knows?

Kernewek: Nyns ov mar dha dell o ev.
English: I am not as good as he was.

Kernewek: Janet yw hirra es Lisa.
English: Janet is taller than Liza.

Kernewek: Bronn Wennili yw an ughella menydh yn Kernow.
English: Brown Willy is the highest mountain in Cornwall.

Kernewek: Kyn hwelas an lyther, ny redyas ger anodho.
English: Though he saw the letter, he did not read a word of it.

Kernewek: Kynth o an gewer toemm, nyns eth hi dhe'n dre mes gortos tre.
English: Though the weather was hot, she did not go to town but stayed home.

Kernewek: An re ma yw mar dha avel hemma, dell glewav.
English: These are as good as this, I hear.

Kernewek: Nyns yw an wivrenn mar hir avel an huni arall.
English: The wire is not as long as the other one.

Kernewek: Bys dhe'n eur ma nyns yw an gewer mar lyb dell o hi de.
English: Until now the weather is not as wet as it was yesterday.

Kernewek: Nyns ov mar dhrog avella, dell dybav.
English: I am not as bad as they, I think.

Kernewek: Yw Margh mar drist dell o ev Dy' Sul?
English: Is Mark as sad as he was on Sunday?

Kernewek: Hware yth omglewis mar lowen avel edhen.
English: Suddenly I felt as happy as a bird.

Kernewek: A nyns yw hy chi mar vyghan avel krow den bal?
English: Isn't her house as small as a miner's hut?

Kernewek: Puptra a vydh mar salow avel chi pronter.
English: Everything will be as safe as a parson's house.

Kernewek: Nyns on ni mar feusik avelli.
English: We are not as lucky as her.

Kernewek: Na gows mar fol!
English: Don't talk so foolishly!

Kernewek: Lowena o mar skav avelov ow tonsya.
English: Lowena was as nimble as me (at) dancing.

Kernewek: Dell glewav, an korev na yw kepar ha dowr toemm.
English: As I hear, that beer is like warm water.

Kernewek: Esta mar oer dell leverydh?
English: Were you as cold as you say?

Kernewek: Mar es yw dyski Kernewek avel dyski ken yeth.
English: It's as easy to learn Cornish as to learn any language.

Kernewek: Dew our diwettha o pan dheuth hi.
English: It was two hours later when she came.

Kernewek: Milvil yw moy es naw kans mil a gans mil.
English: A million is more than nine hundred thousand by a hundred thousand.

Kernewek: Yw korev a'n par na kreffa ages gwin?
English: Is beer of that sort stronger than wine?

Kernewek: Kolan a boenyas dihwans dh'y vamm mes lenta o es y hwoer.
English: Colin ran hard to his mother but he was slower than his sister.

Kernewek: Pandra! An gewer yw braffa lemmyn.
English: What! The weather is finer now.

Kernewek: Y'n Gwenton an eythin yw hwekka es dell yns i y'n Gwav.
English: In the Spring the gorse is sweeter than it is in winter.

Kernewek: Nyns yw an vebyon hirra ages aga hwerydh.
English: The boys are not taller than their sisters.

Kernewek: Hy gour o poessa agessi.
English: Her husband was heavier than she.

Kernewek: Keur an chapel yw brassa es keur eglos an blu martesen.
English: The chapel choir is bigger than the choir of the parish perhaps.

Kernewek: Py lies den yw furra ages Seleven?
English: How many people are wiser than Solomon?

Kernewek: Esedh orth an tan! Ty a vydh toemma ena.
English: Sit at the fire. You will be warmer there.

Kernewek: Py par ydhyn a nij ugella ages an kommol?
English: What kind of birds fly higher than the clouds?

Kernewek: Roger yw moy bysi es y goweth, Les.
English: Roger is busier than his friend, Les.

Kernewek: An dra ma yw an gwettha oll.
English: This affair is the worst of all.

Kernewek: A nyns yw an lew an kreffa enyval y'n norvys?
English: Is not the lion the strongest animal in the world?

Kernewek: An brassa stevell yw an nessa stevell dhe'n wolghva.
English: The biggest room is the nearest room to the bathroom.

Kernewek: Gwari peldroes. Henn yw an gwella gwari!
English: Playing football. That is the best game!

Kernewek: Nag yw! Gwari rygbi yw gwell es gwari peldroes.
English: No! Playing rugby is better than playing football.

Kernewek: An tewa dyenn a vydh pup-prys melyn, mar velyn avel amanenn.
English: The thickest cream is always yellow, as yellow as butter.

Kernewek: Dr Treven o an furra medhyk y'n dre. Nyns esa medhyk furra agesso yn mysk an vedhygyon erell.
English: Dr Tremayne was the wisest doctor in the town. There was no doctor wiser than he amongst the other doctors.

Kernewek: Yma hwans dhymm a wortos ow gwreg yn gorsav an kyttrin.
English: I want to wait for my wife in the bus station.

Kernewek: Puskes a neuv yn dowrow an avon ha'n mor.
English: Fish swim in the waters of the river and the sea.

Kernewek: Res yw dhe bubonan sywya an keth fordh ha'n huni gyns.
English: Everyone must follow the same course as the one before.

Kernewek: Kynth o an galter leun a dhowr bryjys, nyns esa lowr rag peswar hanafas a de.
English: Although the kettle was full of boiled water, there was not enough for four cups of tea.

Kernewek: Kyn hwra an eseli aga ober, nyns yw ev da gans peub anedha.
English: Though the members do their work, not all of them are satisfied with it.

Kernewek: Yth esen vy y'n dre hag a-wosa yn tre arta.
English: I was in town and afterwards at home again.

Kernewek: Yma an vamm ow tiwiska an yowynka flogh.
English: Mother is undressing the youngest child.

Kernewek: Henri a vynn esedha war an isella kador.
English: Henry will sit on the lowest chair.

Kernewek: Ny yll ev esedha war an ughella huni.
English: He cannot sit on the highest one.

Kernewek: An skoloryon, mebyon ha mowesi, a dhe'n keth skol y'n dre.
English: The schoolchildren, boys and girls, go to the same school in town.

Kernewek: Perl a wrug gweres an maw.
English: Pearl helped the boy.

Kernewek: Perl a wrug y weres.
English: Pearl helped him.

Kernewek: Peder a wrug ow gweles.
English: Peter saw me.

Kernewek: Hi a vynn dha glewes.
English: She will hear you.

Kernewek: Lowena a yll y skrifa.
English: Lowena can write it.

Kernewek: My a wra hy hudha.
English: I shall hide it.

Kernewek: Yowann a vynnas agan toella.
English: John wished to deceive us.

Kernewek: Nebonan a wrug agas herdhya.
English: Someone pushed you.

Kernewek: Hwi a allas aga frena.
English: You were able to buy them.

Kernewek: Ny wrug Maria aga gweles ena.
English: Mary didn't see them there.

Kernewek: Piw a vynn ow gweres?
English: Who will help me?

Kernewek: Py flogh a wra y dhyski?
English: Which child will learn it?

Kernewek: Pyth a wra y lanhe?
English: What cleans it?

Kernewek: Pandr'a yll y dhaskorr?
English: What can return it?

Kernewek: Piw a vynn'ta y weles?
English: Whom will you see?

Kernewek: Py chi a wrug Mr Potter y brena?
English: What house did Mr Potter buy?

Kernewek: Pandr'a yllons i y wul?
English: What can they do?

Kernewek: I yw ow mamm ha'm tas.
English: They are my mother and my father.

Kernewek: Pam a dheuth y'n stevell hag esedha ha redya lyver.
English: Pam came into the room, sat down and read a book.

Kernewek: Pam a dheuth y'n stevell hag a esedhas hag a redyas lyver.
English: Pam came into the room and sat down and read a book.

Kernewek: Pam a dheuth y'n stevell ha hi a esedhas ha hi a redyas lyver.
English: Pam came into the room and she sat down and she read a book.

Kernewek: Pam a dheuth y'n stevell mes ny redyas hi lyver.
English: Pam came into the room but she did not read a book.

Kernewek: Pam a dheuth y'n stevell hag yma hi ena hwath.
English: Pam came into the room and she is still there.

Kernewek: Pam a dheuth y'n stevell ha my a gewsis orti.
English: Pam came into the room and I spoke to her.

Kernewek: Plema'n boes, mar pleg? Meg a wra y bareusi.
English: Where is the food, please? Meg is going to prepare it.

Kernewek: Ny allav y drelya yn Sowsnek.
English: I can't translate it into English.

Kernewek: Piw a yll aga dannvon dhodho dh'aga frevi.
English: Who can send them to him to test them?

Kernewek: Ni a vynn y dhiwedha a-dhistowgh.
English: We will finish it straightaway.

Kernewek: Kemmer an wedrenn arta. Ny wrug Jenni hy lenwel a win.
English: Take the glass again. Jenny didn't fill it with wine.

Kernewek: A wre'ta agan aswonn? Drog yw genev! Ny wrav agas aswonn.
English: Do you know us? Sorry! I don't know you.

Kernewek: Ottomma an selsigennow ma! Re goth yns, sur. Piw a vynn aga dybri lemmyn?
English: Look here, these sausages! They are too old, surely. Who will eat them now?

Kernewek: A wra an venyn na ow hara? Ny wonn! Ny wonn!
English: Does that woman love me? I don't know! I don't know!

Kernewek: Pubonan a synsis an lovan ha'y thenna.
English: Everyone held the rope and pulled it.

Kernewek: Yma an tas ow palas y'n lowarth. Piw a vynn y weres?
English: Father is digging in the garden. Who will help him?

Kernewek: Meur a draow yw gwerthys.
English: Many things are sold.

Kernewek: An awel o krev. Ny allas an gorholyon dos ogas dhe'n porth.
English: The wind was strong. The ships couldn't come near to the harbour.

Kernewek: An tasow-wynn a esedhas warbarth yn-mes a'n diwotti ha klappya.
English: The grandfathers sat together outside the pub and chatted.

Kernewek: Yma an gath a'y growedh war an leur yn-dann an gador y'n esedhva.
English: The cat is lying on the floor under the chair in the sitting room.

Kernewek: Eus arghans lowr y'n arghantti rag prena karr nowydh?
English: Is there enough money in the bank to buy a new car?

Kernewek: Eus arghans lowr dhyn ynno?
English: Have we enough money in it?

Kernewek: Noy Mr Stevens yw moen ha'y nith yw tew.
English: Mr Stevens's nephew is slim and his niece is fat.

Kernewek: Ro dhedhi hy eskisyow gell, mar pleg.
English: Give her her brown shoes, please.

Kernewek: Dhe by eur yth yw an tren dhe Loundres an dohajydh ma?
English: At what time is the train to London this afternoon?

Kernewek: Yma tren skav dhe dhiw eur marnas teyr mynysenn warn ugens.
English: There is a fast train at twenty-three minutes to two.

Kernewek: Otta! An lavrek ma yw re verr ragov.
English: Look! These trousers are too short for me.

Kernewek: Res yw dhis prena lavrek nowydh ytho.
English: You must buy new trousers then.

Kernewek: Yth esa syghes bras dhymmo vy hag yth evis gwedrennas a gorev a-dhistowgh.
English: I had a great thirst and I drank a glassful of beer straightaway.

Kernewek: Nebes podigow yw terrys, re erell yw plos. Ny yll den eva leth anedha.
English: Some jugs are broken, others are dirty. No one can drink milk from them.

Kernewek: Usi an amaris orth an fos? Ymons!
English: Are the cupboards against the wall? Yes!

Kernewek: Nyns eus gesys kestenenn y'n koes, dell dybav.
English: There isn't a chestnut tree left in the wood, I think.

Kernewek: Martesen onan goth hepken.
English: Perhaps an old one only.

Kernewek: Syns dornla an daras ha trel e!
English: Catch hold of the door handle and turn it!

Kernewek: Py lies mildir yw an fordh dhe Druru a Essa?
English: How many miles is the road to Truro from Saltash?

Kernewek: Kanow agan bro yw hwekka ages kanow broyow erell.
English: The songs of our land are sweeter than the songs of other lands.

Kernewek: Ni a dhybris li. Ena ni a gerdhas. Kerdh hir o dhe'n kerrek war an hal
English: We ate lunch. Then we walked. It was a long walk to the rocks on the moor.

Kernewek: Lost aga hi yw shyndys.
English: Their dog's tail is injured.

Kernewek: Poes o genen pysi Martyn a weres gans an hwel mes da o ganso agan gweres.
English: We were reluctant to ask Martin to help us with the work but he was glad to help us.

Kernewek: Golgh an badell vras kyns hy gorra yn amari an gegin.
English: Wash the big saucepan before putting it in the kitchen cupboard.

Kernewek: Jen a skubas strel daras an chi gans skubell gales ha strel an esedhva gans skubell vedhel.
English: Jane swept the door mat of the house with a hard brush and the lounge mat with a soft brush.

Kernewek: Ewnter Frank a droghas skorrennow gans heskenn hag ev a wrug aga gorra war an tansys yn y lowarth.
English: Uncle Frank cut branches with a saw and he put them on a bonfire in his garden.

Kernewek: An gwithyas-kres a yskynnas an skeul bys dhe fenester an ughella chambour.
English: The policeman went up the ladder as far as the window of the highest bedroom.

Kernewek: Na hwarth! My re gollas an sebon y'n dowr. Res yw dhymm y hwilas.
English: Don't laugh! I've lost the soap in the water. I must look for it.

Kernewek: Fatell yll hi bywa heb pellgowser yn hy chi?
English: How can she live without a telephone in her house?

Kernewek: An vamm-wynn re verwis a-dhistowgh.
English: Grandmother has died suddenly.

Kernewek: Wosa li y kevis vy pal ha mos yn-mes dhe balas y'n lowarth a-rag an chi.
English: After lunch I got a spade and went out to dig in the front garden.

Kernewek: Prag y harmas ev?
English: Why did he shout?

Kernewek: Prag yth evas hi an te toeth da?
English: Why did she drink the tea very quickly?

Kernewek: Prag y trigas Mighal tre?
English: Why did Michael stay home?

Kernewek: Prag na vynnydh jy gortos penn an gwari? Drefenn ow bos helergh ow tehweles tre.
English: Why don't you wait for the end of the play? Because I shall be late returning home.

Kernewek: Prag y prenas Pol an korev? Drefenn ow bos heb arghans.
English: Why did Paul buy the beer? Because I was without money.

Kernewek: Prag y teuthons i ena? Drefenn bos hwans dhedha a'gan gweles.
English: Why did they come then? Because they wanted to see us.

Kernewek: Prag y targanas an gwas kewer deg hag yma hi ow kul glaw? Drefenn ev dhe vos gokki, sur.
English: Why did the fellow forecast fine weather and it's raining? Because he was silly, certainly.

Kernewek: Prag y hworfennowgh agas ober dhe beder eur pub Dy' Gwener? Drefenn bos hwans dhyn a vones tre moy a-varr.
English: Why do you finish your work at four o'clock every Friday? Because we want to go home earlier.

Kernewek: Prag y tybydh yndella? Drefenn nag eus ken fordh dhe dybi.
English: Why do you think so? Because there is no other way to think.

Kernewek: Prag nag esosta ow skoedhya dha goweth? Drefenn nag ov mar anfur dhe wul henna y'n prys ma.
English: Why are you not supporting your friend? Because I am not so unwise (as) to do that this time.

Kernewek: Prag y tregh ev an skorrennow na? Drefenn ev dh'aga leski war an tansys.
English: Why does he cut those branches? Because he burns them on the bonfire.

Kernewek: Prag na worr Hykka y basti y'n forn? Drefenn ev dh'y dhybri yeyn.
English: Why doesn't Dick put his pasty in the oven? Because he eats it cold.

Kernewek: Yma fleghes ow kwari yn garth-gwari an skol vyghan. Re anedha yw bysi. Yma re erell a'ga sav orth fos an keth skol.
English: There are children playing in the playground of the little school. Some of them are busy. Others are standing against the wall of the same school.

Kernewek: Prag yma an re ma ow sevel yndella? Martesen drefenn aga bos skwith. I re worfennas aga gwari ynsi.
English: Why are these standing in this way? Perhaps because they are tired. They have finished their game.

Kernewek: 'Osta lewyer an karr ma, syrr?' yn-medh an gwithyas kres. 'Ov!' Mr Karn a worthybis. 'Pandr'a hwer?'
English: 'Are you the driver of this car, Sir?' the policeman said. 'I am!' Mr Carne replied. 'What's afoot?'

Kernewek: 'Yma diwros war an fordh ena ha gour shyndys a'y wrowedh war an leur', an gwithyas kres a leveris. 'Res yw dhis gortos deg mynysenn, mar pleg. Ni a vynn y worra dhe'n klavji a-dhistowgh.'
English: 'There's a bicycle on the road there and a man lying injured.' replied the policeman. 'You must wait ten minutes, please. We will take him to hospital immediately.'

Kernewek: 'My a vynn agas skoedhya y'n dra ma,' Mr Karn a leveris. 'A allav vy agas gweres?'
English: 'I will support you in that,' Mr Carne said. 'Can I help you?'

Kernewek: An glaw yw tynna es dell o de. Nyns o an dhargan gwir, my a dyb.
English: The rain is more intense than it was yesterday. The forecast was not true, I think.

Kernewek: Yma jynn-ebrenn ughel a-ugh an kommol. A yll'ta y glewes?
English: There's an aeroplane high above the clouds. Can you hear it?

Kernewek: Gallav mes ny allav y weles.
English: I can but I cannot see it.

Kernewek: Ro dhymm dha drigva ha'th hanow, mar pleg.
English: Give me your name and address, please.

Kernewek: Oll ahanowgh yw Kernewegoryon mes nebes ahanowgh yw gwell ages re erell.
English: All of you are Cornish speakers but some of you are better than others.

Kernewek: Igor gorher an badell! Pyth eus yn-danno?
English: Open the lid of the saucepan. What's beneath it?

Kernewek: Piw a appos an lewyoryon-taksi y'n ranndir ma?
English: Who examines the taxi drivers in this district?

Kernewek: Esowgh hwi ow kwaytya kerdh an olifanses ha'n kowrvergh ha'n enyvales erell dre gres an dre? Soweth, gyllys yns. I eth alemma seulabrys dhe deyr eur poran.
English: Are you waiting for the procession of the elephants and the camels through the town centre? A pity, they are gone. They went from here at three o'clock exactly.

Kernewek: Pan o Pamela difun, hi a wolghas an lestri ha'ga gorra y'n gloes.
English: When Pamela was awake, she washed the dishes and put them in the rack.
